prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author of the situation is in the wrong. The scenario involves a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, leading to conflicts with the wife's ability to manage household tasks and her own work. 

First, the husband chose to work from the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion to use the basement, which is quieter. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs silence. But by working in the bedroom, it restricts the wife's access to the top floor, making it hard for her to do chores, shower, take naps, etc. She's handling most of the housework and childcare, which is already a lot. 

The key points here are communication and compromise. The wife offered an alternative (basement) which he rejected. Now, his choice is causing her significant inconvenience. While he's entitled to a quiet workspace, the wife isn't obligated to sacrifice her own needs. The basement option was viable, so his insistence on the bedroom prioritizes his preferences over hers. 

On the other hand, maybe the wife could have been more flexible, but the husband's setup is the root cause. The question is whether she's in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed. Since he's the one who chose the location despite knowing the consequences, the responsibility lies more on him. The wife is just highlighting the impracticality of his choice. So the answer is B (the author is not in the wrong).
